Graphical abstract Facile synthesis of superficial Pd nanoparticles supported on carbonaceous SBA-15 (denoted as Pd/@SBA-15) as a new hydrotreating catalyst with enhanced activity and sulfur tolerance was accomplished for the production of partially hydrogenated fatty acid methyl esters (H-FAME), a high-quality biodiesel fuel enriched in monosaturated fatty acid methyl esters (mono-FAME) that can be used in high blends. Characterization, especially high-resolution electron microscopes and temperature-programmed techniques, indicated that the Pd nanoparticles (∼7 nm) formed spontaneously at the superficial area of carbonaceous SBA-15 with a hydrophobic surface and low acidity. In the synthesis of H-FAME using commercial palm oil-derived biodiesel fuel as a feedstock under mild conditions (<100 °C, 1 MPa), this new Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst offered high hydrotreating activity with excellent selectivity toward mono-FAME, especially the cis product, and high sulfur resistance, presumably due to fast diffusion and suitable interactions of the reactant and hydrogenated molecules through superficial Pd nanoparticles on the carbonaceous surfaces as the catalytically active sites. On the other hand, commercial Pd catalysts with Pd nanoparticles randomly impregnated inside the supporting materials showed lower activity in H-FAME synthesis and poorer selectivity toward saturated fatty acid methyl esters as undesirable products and lower sulfur tolerance level per Pd site, demonstrating the superiority of our system. Keywords Upgrading of biodiesel fuel Supported Pd catalysts Mesoporous materials Surface characterization High blends for CO2 reduction 1 Introduction Biodiesel fuel (BDF), which mainly consists of fatty acid methyl esters (FAME), is industrially synthesized by alkali-catalyzed transesterification of refined vegetable oils with methanol under mild conditions and subsequent processing steps for separation, purification, and stabilization [1–5]. BDF is generally considered a renewable fuel with a relatively low carbon footprint and is thus widely blended in petro-diesel to reduce CO2 emissions in the transport sector, which is closely linked to global warming and climate change [6–8]. In the region represented by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), palm oil has become a major oil feedstock for the production of palm oil-derived biodiesel fuel (denoted as palm-BDF), especially in Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia, in the past decade in addition to being consumed [9]. Recently, palm-BDF has been extensively blended with petro-diesel to produce B5-B30 fuels, varied by the energy polices of nations and prefectures of ASEAN. Palm-BDF blended fuels with a concentration of FAME that is higher than 5 vol% are known as high-blend fuels. The blending of petro-diesel with palm-BDF not only reduces the dependence of fossil energy in these countries but would also create a new agricultural market to improve the income and quality of life of farmers. To ensure that palm-BDF can be extensively used in the transport sector, the Alternative Energy Development Plan (AEDP2015-2036) legislated by the Royal Thai government has aimed to increase the blending ratio of palm-BDF with petro-diesel from the current 7 vol% to 10 vol% by 2021 and to 20 vol% by 2036 [10]. However, several technical issues such as deposits formed in the injector, fuel filter clogging, and phase separation must be resolved to ensure that high-blend fuels can be used for conventional diesel cars with absolute safety and security [11–16]. Palm-BDF comprises approximately 10 vol% polyunsaturated fatty acid methyl esters (termed poly-FAME), which are poor in terms of oxidation stability, and trace amounts of impurities such as monoglycerides and steryl glucosides, which make it degrade and precipitate over time. Our recent studies have demonstrated that high-blend fuels (B7-B20) formulated by blending petro-diesel with commercial palm-BDFs degraded severely in the presence of oxygen and heat [17]. There is still room for development of new processes for the production of high-quality palm-BDF with high oxidation stability and fuel property, which can be blended with petro-diesel to form high-blend fuels with no safety issues. Commercial BDFs with enhanced oxidation stability are generally obtained by adding antioxidant additives, such as 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol (BHT) [18–21]. However, the antioxidant additives may have positive or negative effects on the fuel properties of the blend fuels, which are related to the types of BDFs blended. There is no universal additive that can be used to stabilize all kinds of blended fuels. The phase separation of additives and blended fuels is another technical problem, especially for high-blend fuels; however, it has not been discussed in detail so far. A novel strategy to upgrade commercial BDFs with poor oxidation stability into partially hydrogenated fatty acid methyl esters (H-FAME) - a new group of high-quality BDF enriched in monounsaturated fatty acid methyl esters (denoted as mono-FAME) - with high oxidation stability and uncompromised cold-flow properties involves using transition metal catalysts (Ni, Pt, and Pd) under mild hydrogenation conditions (<120 °C and 1 MPa) [17,22–34]. High-blend fuels formulated by blending petro-diesel with H-FAME offer reliable fuel properties and stability for conventional vehicles with diesel engines [17,34]. More importantly, H-FAME can be synthesized from any kind of BDF derived from various vegetable oils and fish fats, especially low-grade feedstocks [34], although the reaction conditions need to be further optimized. Thus, the use of H-FAME can be a universal solution for synthesizing high-blend fuels for use in all kinds of diesel cars. However, the technology that produces high-quality H-FAME with the desirable composition of poly-FAME, mono-FAME, and saturated fatty acid methyl esters (denoted as sat-FAME) by varying the degree of hydrogenation of various BDFs over transition metal catalysts is significantly dependent on the structural properties of the catalysts [25–27,35–41], the compositions and impurities of BDFs [17,28], the reaction parameters, and the types of the reactors [42]. Among transition metal catalysts, supported Pd catalysts show excellent activity and selectivity in the selective hydrogenation of poly-FAME molecules into the corresponding mono-FAME molecules with good oxidation stability and uncompromised cold-flow properties, which is the major component of H-FAME [17,24–28]. In contrast, supported Pt catalysts with high hydrotreating activity can undertake full hydrogenation of poly-FAME molecules into sat-FAME with compromised cold-flow property, which is undesirable for high-blend fuels. Supported Ni catalysts with relatively low hydrotreating activity offer low activity in the synthesis of H-FAME under mild conditions [24]. Recent studies have shown that the activity of supported Pd catalysts in the synthesis of H-FAME could be enhanced by tuning the property and acidity of the supports and the size of Pd particles [25–28,39–41]. For example, mesoporous silica-supported Pd catalysts with a large surface area and well-dispersed Pd nanoparticles were superior to commercial alumina-supported Pd catalysts in upgrading palm-BDF into H-FAME [17,26,27]. However, it has been reported that supported Pd catalysts undergo deactivation owing to impurities, especially sulfur species, that are originally present in commercial palm-BDFs [25,27,28]. The isomerization of cis-mono-FAME with better cold-flow properties to the trans counterpart with poorer cold-flow properties is another technical problem. This side reaction is presumably catalyzed by Pd nanoparticles impregnated inside the lengthy pores with low accessibility and slow molecular diffusibility. It is imperative to develop new supported Pd catalysts with tunable structural properties that can offer high activity, selectivity, and sulfur resistance in the synthesis of H-FAME with desirable FAME composition, particularly for H-FAME derived from commercial palm-BDF containing some sulfur species. In this study, a mesoporous silica material - as-prepared SBA-15 (denoted as @SBA-15) with an outer surface of ∼100 m2  g−1 - was directly used as a supporting material. P123 molecules originally present in the channeling pores and outer surface were used as a carbon source. To increase the molecular diffusion, Pd nanoparticles were specifically supported on the superficial surface (i.e., outer surface and pore mouths) of carbonaceous SBA-15 (denoted as Pd/@SBA-15) through the incipient impregnation of a Pd precursor solution on the @SBA-15, followed by carbonization at 400–550 °C under an atmosphere of nitrogen or air. The structural properties of the resulting Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts were characterized by various techniques such as high-resolution electron microscopes and temperature-programmed techniques. The characterization results were correlated to their catalytic performance in the synthesis of palm H-FAME under mild reaction conditions (<100 °C and 0.8 MPa of H2). The composition of palm H-FAME was discussed along with the stability of the B30 fuel formulated by blending palm H-FAME with petro-diesel. Moreover, the hot filtration test and enhanced sulfur tolerance of Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts have been reported here for the first time, and the results were compared to those obtained using commercial carbon-supported Pd catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of mesoporous silica SBA-15 The mesoporous silica material SBA-15 was prepared through self-assembly of Pluronic P123 as a pore directing agent and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as a silica precursor in an acidic solution [43–46]. Pluronic P123 is a triblock copolymer comprising poly(ethylene oxide), denoted as PEO, and poly(propylene oxide), denoted as PPO, with a chemical formula of PEO20PPO70PEO20 and an average molecular weight of 5800. Typically, 4.0 g of the Pluronic P123 triblock copolymer (Sigma-Aldrich, MW = 5800) and 1.18 g of NaCl (Wako) were thoroughly dissolved in 80 g of a 2 M HCl solution at 35 °C under vigorous stirring. To this solution, 8.4 g of TEOS (Wako) was added under stirring for 5 min. The resulting solution had a molar P123:TEOS:HCl:NaCl:H2O ratio of 0.017:1:7.9:0.5:204. For the self-assembly, this solution was aged at 35 °C for 24 h under static conditions and then hydrothermally treated at 100 °C under static conditions for another 24 h. The resulting white precipitates were then filtered, fully washed by deionized water, and dried at 100 °C overnight to obtain the as-prepared SBA-15 mesoporous silica material with P123 pore-directing agents inside the channeling pores and outer surfaces (namely @SBA-15). 2.2 Preparation of Pd/@SBA-15 The as-prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst was prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation method. Previous studies demonstrated that the transition metal ions could chelate with the hydrophilic PEO moieties of P123 through weak coordination bonds, which interaction has been extensively used for preparation of mesoporous transition oxides and metal-incorporated SBA-15 materials [5,46,47]. In this study, the Pd species were chelated with the PEO groups of P123 to form the as-made Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts via impregnation, and then converted into Pd nanoparticles associated with the carbonaceous layer in the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts by carbonization in a nitrogen atmosphere. Before the impregnation, the @SBA-15 support was dried at 100 °C, followed by transferring into a round-bottom flask and drying again at room temperature under a low-pressure condition (<0.1 torr). Then, an aqueous solution of Pd(NH3)4Cl2・xH2O (N.E. CHEMCAT, Pd =40.16 wt%) was slowly dropped on the @SBA-15 support, resulting in the as-prepared Pd/@SBA-15. The Pd loading was maintained at 1 wt% against SiO2. The as-prepared Pd/@SBA-15 was aged under a low-pressure condition (∼0.1 torr) for 1 h, followed by drying under microwave irradiation (1050 W, 50 Hz) for 10 min. Carbonization was performed in an atmosphere of N2 at 400 °C or 550 °C using a ramp rate of 1 °C min−1 for 3 h. As a result, the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 and N550-Pd/SBA-15 catalysts were obtained, where “N” represents calcination in a nitrogen atmosphere. For comparison, the A400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst was prepared by incomplete combustion of the as-prepared Pd/@SBA-15 sample at 400 °C at a ramp rate of 1 °C min−1 for 3 h in air. Commercial Pd catalysts were used as reference catalysts and their characterization results are shown in the supporting information (Figures S1-3, ESI). One was a mesoporous γ-alumina-supported Pd catalyst with a Pd particle size and loading of 1.5 nm and 0.5 wt%, respectively (termed 0.5 wt%Pd/γ-Al2O3), kindly supplied by a Japanese catalyst company. This 0.5 wt%Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst consisted of a thin layer of Pd coated on the mesoporous alumina sphere, which offered a relatively high performance for use in alkene hydrogenation. The surface area, pore volume, and mesopore size were 143 m2 g−1, 0.58 cm3 g−1, and 10.3 nm, respectively. The other was a microporous carbon-supported Pd catalyst with a Pd size and loading of 4.8 nm and 5 wt%, respectively (termed 5 wt%Pd/Carbon), purchased from FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation (product code: 165-07542). The surface area, pore volume, and pore size were 931 m2 g−1, 0.74 cm3 g−1, and 1.1 nm, respectively. 2.3 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded by a Bruker D2 PHASER diffractometer using Cu Kα irradiation. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were acquired by a BELSORP-max instrument at 77 K. Before the measurement, the prepared samples were degassed at 150 °C for 10 h under high vacuum (∼ 10−5 torr). The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method in the P/P 0 region of 0.05–0.25. The total pore volume was accumulated up to a P/P 0 ratio of 0.95. The pore size distribution (PSD) was analyzed by the non-local density function theory (NLDFT) method using a slit model. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Rigaku Thermo plus Evo2 TG8120 instrument. The prepared samples were loaded in an alumina holder and heated from room temperature to 800 °C at 10 °C min-1 under a N2 atmosphere or in air. CO pulse chemisorption was achieved employing an Okura Riken R6015 instrument at 50 °C, assuming a stoichiometric CO/Pd ratio of 1. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) analysis was performed on a BelCatII instrument equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and mass spectrometry (MS). The samples (100 ± 5 mg) were finely sandwiched between quartz wood with a thermocouple inserted in the center, and then purged by Ar flow (50 mL min-1) for 60 min prior to H2-TPR measurements. The H2-TPR profiles were recorded by both TCD and MS detectors in the temperature range from –50 to 300 °C at a ramping rate of 2 °C min-1 under a standard gas of 5.05 vol%H2/Ar and calibrated by a 1.05 vol%H2/Ar standard gas. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was also performed by a BelCatII instrument using a similar procedure as the one described above. Prior to the NH3-TPD measurement, the dried samples were reduced at 300 °C by a H2 flow (50 mL g-1) for 1 h, purged by Ar flow, and cooled to 50 °C, and then ammonia was adsorbed using a standard gas of 5.0 vol% NH3/He for 30 min at 50 °C, followed by purging with Ar flow (50 mL min-1) for another hour. The NH3-TPD profiles were recorded in the temperature range of 50–500 °C. The Pd size and size distribution were statistically analyzed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) using a JEOL JEM-2100 instrument. The morphology and Pd location of prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts were examined by high-resolution scanning electron microscope (HRSEM) using a field emission JEOL JSM-7500 F instrument. 2.4 Synthesis of palm H-FAME Commercial palm-BDF was kindly supplied by a regional producer in Thailand and thoroughly analyzed according to the specifications of the standard EN14214 [2,5,17]. Table 1 shows the fatty acid compositional profile of this palm-BDF, which is similar to literature reports [17,48]. However, it should be noted that this palm BDF had been stored in the ambient condition for nearly 2 years so that some of its fuel properties, such as acid value (max. 0.5 mKOH g−1) and oxidation stability (min. 10 h), did not meet with the EN14214 standard due to degradation. As a potential method to improve the fuel properties, which will be discussed later, partial hydrogenation of this palm-BDF over the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts into palm H-FAME was performed in a TEM-V series batch-type reaction system (Taiatsu Techno. Corp., Japan) using a Hiper glass reactor under mild conditions. The reaction temperature and hydrogen pressure were controlled in the ranges of 40–100 °C and 0.3–0.8 MPa, respectively. The catalyst/oil weight ratios were varied over the range 0.33–0.83 wt%, corresponding to Pd/oil weight ratios of 3.33–8.33 × 10-5. In a typical synthesis, palm-BDF (150 g) was heated from room temperature to 80 °C in 8 min under an atmosphere pressure of hydrogen without stirring. To start the reaction, the reduced catalyst (1.0 g) was quickly added to the commercial palm BDF, and the reaction system was pressurized by hydrogen and vigorously stirred (1000 rpm). Hydrogenated oils were sampled at specific intervals and analyzed by the EN14103 and EN14105 methods using an Agilent gas chromatography (GC) 6890 N instrument equipped with a HP-88 capillary column (100 m in length, 0.25 mm in diameter, and 0.2 μm in thickness) and a DB-5HT capillary column (30 m in length, 0.25 mm in diameter, and 0.1 μm in thickness), respectively [5,17]. Noted that the hydrotreated oils were lost a little during the sampling, filtration and analysis. Thus, the mass balances were around 98 % for all the reaction experiments. Reproducibility of the reaction experiments was examined, which had an error of less than 10 %. 2.5 Kinetic analysis Hydrogenation of commercial palm BDF over the supported Pd catalysts, including the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts and several commercial Pd catalysts, to form palm H-FAME involves a consecutive hydrogenation reaction. The poly-FAME molecules are hydrogenated to mono-FAME and subsequently to sat-FAME as described by Eq. 1. (1) A → k 1 B → k 2 C where A, B, and C represent the poly-FAME, mono-FAME, and sat-FAME components, respectively. As shown in Table 1, the poly-FAME and mono-FAME components were mostly related to 9,12-octadecadienoic acid methyl ester (C18:2 FAME, 8.10 wt.%) and cis-9-Octadecenoic acid methyl ester (cis-C18:1 FAME, 38.1 wt.%), respectively. The sat-FAME components were mostly related to hexadecanoic acid methyl ester (C16:0 FAME, 44.75 wt.%) in addition to small amounts of octadecanoic acid methyl ester (C18:0 FAME, 4.56 wt.%) and other saturated FAME molecules. The rate constant (k1 ) for the hydrogenation of A to B can be estimated using Eq. 2. (2) r A = d A d t = - k 1 A Similarly, the rate constant (k2 ) for the formation of C can be determined by Eq. 3. (3) r C = d C d t = k 2 C The rate constants k1 and k2 were obtained by curve fitting of the experimental data using the Polymath 6.1 software (Professional version, SWREG Digital River) according to procedures reported previously [25,42,49]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Pd/@SBA-15 The thermal stability of the P123 triblock copolymer in the as-prepared sample of Pd/@SBA-15 was investigated by TGA in N2 atmosphere or air. The results are shown in Fig. 1 (a). When the TGA data were recorded in air, the as-prepared Pd/@SBA-15 sample showed three weight loss signals, associated with the (i) desorption of physically adsorbed water (<150 °C), (ii) decomposition of PPO blocks inside the mesopores (150–210 °C), and (iii) decomposition of PEO blocks embedded in the micropores (>210 °C) [44–46]. The silica residue content was 57 wt.%, which is close to the values quoted in literature [50–54]. When the TGA data were recorded in N2, the weight loss signals corresponding to the decomposition of the PPO and PEO blocks shifted to higher temperatures and the residues increased to 72 wt.%, indicating that the P123 molecules were relatively stable in the N2 atmosphere and a fraction of them (∼15 wt.%) was converted to carbon residues on the SBA-15 surface. In this study, the as-prepared Pd/@SBA-15 sample was thermally treated at 400–550 °C in N2, resulting in N400-Pd/@SBA-15 and N550-Pd/@SBA-15 samples, whereas calcination of a counterpart was undertaken at 400 °C in air, resulting in an A400-Pd/@SBA-15 sample. Effects of the calcination conditions (temperature and atmosphere) on the carbon residues and surface properties of the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts were then studied through TGA in air. The results are shown in Fig. 1(b). For calcination at 400 °C in air, the resultant A400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst showed two weight loss signals, associated with the (i) desorption of physically adsorbed water (1.8 wt.%) at the temperature below 100 °C and (ii) removal of carbon residues and further condensation of the silica framework (1.1 wt.%) at 200–650 °C. The A400-Pd/@SBA-15 sample was a pale-yellow powder, presumably due to the presence of a small amount of carbon residues derived from the incomplete combustion of P123 molecules when the as-prepared Pd/@SBA-15 sample was calcined at 400 °C in air. For the calcination condition of 400 °C and N2 atmosphere, the resultant N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst showed a relatively low amount of physically adsorbed water (0.6 wt%) at temperatures lower than 150 °C, which corresponds to a hydrophobic surface, and a stepwise weight loss (approx. 7 wt%) over a wide temperature range of 200–650 °C, which is related to the removal of carbon residues derived from the PEO and PPO blocks accompanying condensation of the silica framework. Due to incomplete thermal pyrolysis and removal of P123 molecules at 400 °C in N2, the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst contained more carbon residues on the hydrophobic surface in comparison to the A400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst. When the calcination temperature was increased to 550 °C in N2, the resultant N550-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst gave small weight loss signals of water (∼1.8 wt.%) and no carbon residues (<1 wt.%), indicating that the silica surface was clean and hydrophilic due to complete pyrolysis of P123. Influence of the calcination conditions on the structural properties of prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts was examined by XRD, N2 physisorption, elemental analysis, and electron microscopy. Fig. 2 (A) shows three diffraction peaks for the Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts in the small-angle region, corresponding to the (100), (110), and (200) planes of the 2D hexagonal p6mm pore structure [43]. The diffraction peaks of prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts after the thermal treatment in air or nitrogen are stronger than those of as-prepared SBA-15 (namely @SBA-15). It is due to the electron contrast between the pores and inorganic framework increasing owing to removal of most of the P123 molecules inside the pores of Pd/@SBA-15. On the other hand, the diffraction peaks in the small-angle region shifted to a higher 2θ region, corresponding to a smaller d-spacing, which were disproportional to the calcination temperature. This is associated with structural shrinkage of the mesoporous silica framework via further condensation of silanol groups under thermal treatment. In Fig. 2(B), the wide-angle XRD patterns show that the @SBA-15 sample had a broad band centered at ∼20–25°, associated with the amorphous silica framework. For the calcined Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts, several diffraction peaks can be observed at 2θ = 33.9°, 41.9°, 54.7°, 60.3°, and 71.3°, corresponding to the (101), (110), (112), (103), and (202) planes of PdO nanoparticles. The PdO particle sizes were determined by the Scherrer equation using the peak width of the (101) plane. The results show that the PdO sizes of N400-Pd/@SBA-15, N550-Pd/@SBA-15, and A400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts were ∼5.2, 10.4, and 6.6 nm, respectively. Fig. 3 shows the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and NLDFT pore size distributions of @SBA-15 and Pd/@SBA-15 samples. The @SBA-15 sample shows a type IV isotherm with a small H1 hysteresis loop, indicating that P123 molecules remained in the @SBA-15 sample. For the Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts prepared by thermal treatment at 400–550 °C in N2 or at 400 °C in air, classical type IV isotherms with a deep H1 hysteresis loop are observed, which imply that P123 mostly decomposed into small gas molecules owing to the thermal treatment in air. However, a fraction of them could be transformed into a carbanceous layer on the superficial area when P123 was thermally treated in N2 [5]. The structural properties of the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts are summarized in Table 2 , along with those of @SBA-15 and three commercial Pd catalysts. The @SBA-15 sample with P123 molecules inside the mesopores had a relatively low surface area and pore volume. By contrast, the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts showed a high surface area (>600 m2 g−1) and large pore volume (>0.9 cm3 g−1) and relatively small mesopores (∼5 nm). The Pd sizes of the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts were determined by CO pulse chemisorption. All the samples were reduced by a hydrogen flow (50 mL min−1) at 300 ℃ before the measurement at 50 ℃ under an atmosphere of helium. The CO chemisorption data show that the Pd sizes of the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts were 5.7–14.5 nm and varied with the conditions of the thermal treatment. The N550-Pd/SBA-15 catalyst prepared by a thermal treatment of 550 °C and subsequent reduction exhibited the largest Pd size [55]. The N400-Pd/SBA-15 catalyst showed the smallest Pd sizes, suggesting that the Pd precursor impregnated on @SBA-15 can be converted into small PdO species by thermal treatment at 400 °C in N2 and subsequently reduced to metallic Pd nanoparticles with a similar size on the carbonaceous surface. In contrast, the A400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst showed relatively large Pd particles, probably due to the aggregation of Pd species owing to calcination in air and subsequent reduction on the siliceous surface. It should be mentioned again that the Pd species was specifically impregnated on the as-prepared SBA-15 sample (i.e., @SBA-15). After thermal treatment and reduction, Pd nanoparticles should be formed on the outer surface or pore mouths of @SBA-15 so that the Pd sizes of the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts would be similar in size to or slightly larger than the mesopores. The microstructures of prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts were investigated by HRTEM (Fig. 4 ). Three prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts with well-dispersed Pd nanoparticles and highly ordered 2D hexagonal pore structures are observed. The Pd particle size and distribution were statistically analyzed using more than 50 particles in the HRTEM images. The results show that the Pd sizes of N400-Pd/@SBA-15, N550-Pd/@SBA-15, and A400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts were 6.6 nm, 10.5 nm, and 7.6 nm, respectively. These results are consistent with those of XRD patterns, N2 physisorption, and CO chemisorption mentioned above. The locations of Pd nanoparticles within the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts were carefully examined by HRSEM images using the detection modes of secondary electron (SE) and back-scattering electron (BSE), as shown in Fig. 5 (a,c,e) and Fig. 5(b,d,f), respectively. For the HRSEM images using the SE detection mode, the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts showed rod-like aggregates with a characteristic fingerprint and very small particles on the superficial area, which are associated with a mesoporous structure and superficial Pd nanoparticles, respectively. The HRSEM images using the BSE detection mode Fig. 5(b,d,f) reveal that those bright spots in Fig. 5(a,c,e) were indeed Pd nanoparticles, mostly formed on the outer surface or pore months of prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts. The reducibility and surface acidity of the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts, which will be correlated to their hydrotreating activity and selectivity in the synthesis of H-FAME later, were examined by H2-TPR and NH3-TPD techniques recorded by TCD as shown in Fig. 6 (A) and (B), respectively. For the H2-TPR profiles, intense signals centered at 81, 93, and 90 °C were observed for the N400-Pd/@SBA-15, N550-Pd/@SBA-15, and A400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts, respectively (Fig. 6). This signal (α peak) is associated with the reduction of PdO with hydrogen to metallic Pd° nanoparticles accompanying the formation of water as a product, confirmed by the MS signal recorded for a m/z ratio of 2 corresponding to the hydrogen consumption (Fig. S3, ESI). The reduction of the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst was easier than that of the other two specimens, presumably due to its smaller Pd particles. These results are consistent with the results of XRD and TEM. The commercial 0.5 wt%Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst only gave a small signal of peak α at 93 °C, probably because this catalyst had been reduced before being received. The 5 wt%Pd/Carbon catalyst showed two peaks at 6.9 ℃ and 71 ℃, corresponding to the reduction of PdO to metallic Pd species (peak α) and the release of physically adsorbed hydrogen from the microporous carbon framework (peak β), respectively. For the NH3-TPD study, the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst with carbonaceous surface showed a small signal of NH3 desorption centered at 90 °C, confirmed by the MS signal recorded at a m/z ratio of 16 (Fig. S4, ESI). It indicates that the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst had a low acid strength with a capacity of 0.02 mmol NH3 g−1, presumably due to the siliceous surface being covered by carbon species with low acidity. The commercial 0.5 wt%Pd/γ-Al2O3 and 5 wt%Pd/Carbon catalysts also showed small signals of NH3 desorption centered at relatively high temperatures (115–120 °C) with a shoulder peak at ∼200 °C, corresponding to a moderately acidic capacity with relatively high acidic strength (0.49–0.70 mmol NH3 g−1). In contrast, the N550-Pd/@SBA-15 and A400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts with siliceous surfaces showed distinct signals of NH3 desorption centered at 110–112 °C, corresponding to relatively high acid capacities of 1.08–1.17 mmol NH3 g−1), mainly derived from surface silanol groups. 3.2 Synthesis of palm H-FAME 3.2.1 Catalytic performance of prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts Partial hydrogenation of palm-BDF over the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts into corresponding H-FAME was performed in a batch-type glass reactor with vigorous stirring (1000 rpm) under mild conditions (80 °C and 0.5 MPa of H2), in comparison with commercial 0.5 wt%Pd/γ-Al2O3 and 5 wt%Pd/Carbon catalysts. The amount of palm-BDF as a feedstock was kept at 150 g. The amounts of Pd catalysts were varied in the range of 0.2–1.0 g, corresponding to a fixed Pd/oil weight ratio of 6.7 × 10−5. Fig. 7 shows that all the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts were superior to commercial Pd catalysts in the partial hydrogenation of palm-BDF into corresponding H-FAME under mild reaction conditions, particularly the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst. The activity and selectivity of the prepared Pd catalysts in the synthesis of palm H-FAME were further evaluated by the initial rate, turnover frequency (TOF), T90 value, FAME composition, and kinetic analysis. The initial rate was calculated by dividing the molar fraction of poly-FAME component converted by the catalyst weight in gram at the first 5 min of the reaction. TOF was calculated by dividing the initial rate by the number of Pd active sites per gram of the catalysts, which were determined by the CO chemisorption technique. The T90 value is defined as the reaction time needed to achieve a 90 % of the poly-FAME conversion. These data are tabulated in Table 3 , and compared with results of our previous study using an in-house-prepared 1 wt%Pd/C-SBA-15 catalyst [17]. This 1 wt%Pd/C-SBA-15 catalyst with a Pd loading of 1 wt% (termed Pd/C-SBA-15) was prepared by impregnation of the Pd precursor solution into the channeling pores of calcined SBA-15, which contained no P123 residues, using the same procedures as those mentioned in Section 2.2. The results show that the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts, especially N400-Pd/@SBA-15, had high initial rates in the synthesis of H-FAME at 80 °C and 0.5 MPa of H2, which are higher than those of the commercial 0.5 wt%Pd/γ-Al2O3 and previously reported Pd/C-SBA-15 catalysts, and consequently show relatively small T90 values. In contrast, although the Pd loading of the commercial 5 wt%Pd/Carbon catalyst was 5 times higher than those of prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts, the initial rate of the commercial 5 wt%Pd/Carbon catalyst in the synthesis of palm H- FAME was only enhanced by 2.5–3.9 times compared to that of the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts and it took more than 102 min to reach the T90 value, indicating that the molecular diffusion of FAME molecules through microporous carbon structure was restricted. The TOF values of prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts were 1–2 orders of magnitude higher than those of commercial Pd catalysts and the previously reported catalyst Pd/C-SBA-15. In addition, the palm H-FAMEs synthesized using the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts contained higher amounts of mono-FAME and lower amounts of sat-FAME than those synthesized by commercial Pd catalysts and even the previously reported Pd/C-SBA-15 catalyst (see Table 2 and Fig. S5, ESI). By using the preparation procedure described in this study, superficial Pd nanoparticles were spontaneously formed on the outer surface or pore mouths of carbonaceous SBA-15 with a hydrophobic surface and low acidity so that they were highly accessible to the oil molecules. For the partial hydrogenation of palm-BDF, the diffusion and adsorption of poly-FAME molecules onto the catalytically active sites of metallic Pd nanoparticles on the superficial area of prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts could be facilitated, and they were then reacted with dissociated hydrogen species near the active sites to form the corresponding mono-FAME molecules. The desorption of mono-FAME molecules from the active sites could also be facilitated whereas the reverse was true for further hydrogenation of mono-FAME molecules to corresponding sat-FAME counterparts. As a result, the prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts, especially the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst, were able to produce palm H-FAME with relatively high amounts of mono-FAME and relatively low amounts of sat-FAME. This hypothesis is supported by kinetic analysis, which shows large k1 and small k2 values for the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst in the synthesis of palm H-FAME, corresponding to a large k1 /k2 ratio of 154 (Table S1, ESI). The smaller k1/k2 values of N550-Pd/@SBA-15 and A400-Pd/SBA-15 catalysts should have to do with larger Pd particles impregnaied on the hydrophilic and acidic surface, which give a negative effect on partial hydrogenation of poly-FAME to mono-FAME and subsequent desorption as aforementioned. The kinetic analysis also indicates that the k1 /k2 values were lower for the commercial Pd/Carbon catalyst with a microporous structure and the 0.5 wt%Pd/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with disordered pores and high acidity. Table 1 further shows that palm H-FAME over N400-Pd/@SBA-15 is a new type of high-quality BDF with high oxidation stability and uncompromised cold-flow properties, which is suitable for use in the case of high-blend fuels. B30 fuel formulated by blending of 30 vol% H-FAME and 70 vol% petro-diesel gave high stability against heat and oxygen (Fig. S6, ESI), whereas a counterpart which was formulated by blending of 30 vol% palm-BDF and 70 vol% petro-diesel showed many precipitates with high acid value (> 50 mg g−1) after the accelerated oxidation test (Fig. S7, ESI). On the other hand, the Pd nanoparticles were randomly impregnated in the lengthy channeling pores of Pd/C-SBA-15 or the microporous/disordered pores of commercial Pd catalysts [17]. The relatively low activity of Pd/C-SBA-15 and commercial Pd catalysts in the synthesis of H-FAME should be associated with slow molecular diffusion of oil molecules at the reaction steps as mentioned before [45,46,51]. It also caused deep hydrogenation of poly-FAME molecules to the sat-FAME counterpart. The resulting H-FAMEs with high amounts of sat-FAME molecules, which might precipitate in the winter due to poor cold-flow properties, are unsuitable for use in high blends [14–16]. 3.3 Influences of reaction parameters The catalytic performance of the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst in synthesis of palm H-FAME was further examined by varying the pressure of hydrogen, the reaction temperature, and the amount of the catalyst. When the reaction temperature and Pd/oil ratio were maintained at 80 °C and 6.67 × 10−5, respectively, the conversion of poly-FAME over the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst to corresponding mono-FAME could be accelerated by increasing the reaction pressure from 0.3 MPa to 0.5-0.8 MPa (Fig. 8 ). As for the composition, it was found that the palm H-FAMEs synthesized at the hydrogen pressure of 0.5-0.8 MPa contained relatively high amounts of mono-FAME component and low amounts of sat-FAME component whereas the reverse is true for that synthesized at a hydrogen pressure of 0.3 MPa (Fig. S8, ESI), which is presumably due to that the adsorption and dissociation of hydrogen over Pd surfaces become slow. A longer reaction time is necessary for complete hydrogenation of poly-FAME using a batch-type reactor under mild reaction conditions (i.e., the longer contact time between the reactant molecules and active sites). A portion of mono-FAME is then converted into sat-FAME (i.e. over-hydrogenation). It resulted in a H-FAME product with improper composition. Similarly, increases in poly-FAME conversions were observed on increasing the reaction temperature and the catalyst amount as shown in Figs. 9 and 10 . When the reaction temperature was in the range of 80−100 °C and the Pd/oil weight ratios were in the range of 6.67–8.33 × 10−5, resulting palm H-FAMEs with a relatively high mono-FAME component and low sat-FAME component could be obtained by the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst using a hydrogen pressure of 0.5 MPa (Figs. S9–10, ESI). When the reaction parameters were out of those ranges, long reaction times were necessary for hydrogenation of palm BDF over the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst, causing the palm H-FAMEs to contain too much of sat-FAME components and therefore rendering them unsuitable for use in high blends. It can be said that high-quality palm H-FAME with suitable compositions of poly-FAME (< 1 wt%), mono-FAME (approx. 40–45 wt%) and sat-FAME (50–55 wt%) can be synthesized by partial hydrogenation of palm-BDF over the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst in the batch-type reactor at 80−100 °C and 0.5-0.8 MPa of H2 using Pd/oil weight ratios of 6.67–8.33 × 10−5. The mild operating conditions of the H-FAME process make this an attractive process compared to green diesel produced by severe hydrotreating process (> 300 °C and 1 MPa). 3.4 Hot filtration test and sulfur tolerance The stability of the prepared N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst in the synthesis of palm H-FAME was then examined by the hot filtration tests. After the reaction was carried out for 5 min, the hydrotreated oil was immediately separated from the reaction mixture using a syringe filter, and then heated at the same condition for another 2 h. Fig. 11 shows that no significant change in poly-FAME conversion could be observed, indicating that the leaching of Pd from the prepared N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst can be ignored in the studied reaction conditions. On the other hand, previous studies had shown that the sulfur species poisoned the Pd catalysts in the synthesis of H-FAME, and they are present in commercial BDF at a ppm level [17]. For example, Na Rungsi et al. recently reported that the activity of Pd/MCM-41 in the synthesis of soybean oil-derived BDF dropped significantly even when only 2 ppm of sulfur species was added to the feedstock [49]. In this study, the influence of sulfur species on the activity and selectivity of the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst in the synthesis of palm H-FAME was examined by adding 5 ppm of dibenzothiophene (DBT) to the feedstock of palm-BDF, which originally contained ∼1 ppm of sulfur. DBT is a model compound frequently used in the study of petroleum refining process over the sulfide or metal catalysts [56–58]. As a result, the sulfur-containing palm-BDF with ∼6 ppm of sulfur was used as a feedstock for the study of sulfur tolerance of the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst in the synthesis of palm H-FAME under mild conditions (80 °C, 0.5 MPa of H2, and a Pd/Oil ratio of 6.67 × 10−5), and the results were compared to those obtained for the commercial Pd/Carbon catalyst (Fig. 12 ). The results show that the activity of the N400-Pd/SBA-15 catalyst in the synthesis of palm H-FAME was affected when the palm-BDF containing 6 ppm of sulfur was used as a feedstock. Although the TOF value decreased and T90 value increased (Table S2, ESI), the poly-FAME conversion of the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst in the synthesis of palm H-FAME could still reach nearly 100 % in a relatively short reaction period. Sulfur poisoning was also observed for the synthesis of H-FAME over the commercial Pd/Carbon catalyst. The T90 value of commercial Pd/Carbon catalyst was increased to 182 min when 6 ppm of sulfur was added to a palm-BDF feedstock. A longer reaction period was caused by the poisoning of the Pd sites on the microporous framework with relatively high acidity by adding sulfur species. It resulted a poor H-FAME product containing too much of sat-FAME component. By contrast, the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst still showed high activity in the synthesis of H-FAME even though the palm-BDF containing 6 ppm of sulfur was used as a feedstock. The composition of H-FAME over N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst was better than that of commercial Pd/C catalyst. It might be due to weak adsorption of sulfur species on the Pd nanoparticles impregnated on superficial area of N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst with a carbonaceous layer of hydrophobicity and low acidity. Thus, it can be said that the N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst is superior to the commercial 5 wt.%Pd/Carbon catalyst in the synthesis of palm H-FAME even when palm-BDF containing a relatively high sulfur concentration is used as feedstock. 4 Conclusions A facile method was developed to synthesize superficial Pd nanoparticles supported on the outer surfaces and pore mouths of carbonaceous SBA-15 mesoporous silica. The Pd precursor solution was directly impregnated on the as-prepared SBA-15 material containing P123 templates inside the mesopores and surface, which were used as a carbon source. After carbonization at ∼400 °C, Pd nanoparticles were formed on the superficial area of carbonaceous SBA-15, which showed a hydrophobic surface and low acidity. The prepared Pd/@SBA-15 catalysts, especially N400-Pd/@SBA-15, exhibited high activity and mono-FAME selectivity in the synthesis of palm H-FAME (partial hydrogenation of commercial palm-BDF) under optimized conditions (80−100 °C, 0.5–0.8 MPa of H2, and Pd/Oil weight ratios of 6.67–8.33 × 10−5). Superficial Pd nanoparticles on the carbonaceous SBA-15 with a hydrophobic surface and weak acidity could facilitate partial hydrogenation of poly-FAME molecules into corresponding mono-FAME counterparts due to the rapid molecular diffusion of oil molecules through the Pd nanoparticles and subsequent hydrogenation and desorption. However, the same was not noted for the deep hydrogenation of poly-FAME molecules into corresponding sat-FAME undertaken using commercial Pd/γ-Al2O3 and Pd/Carbon catalysts with Pd nanoparticles in randomly distributed pores or the microporous framework. The N400-Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst was able to produce H-FAME with suitable compositions of poly-FAME (<1 wt%), mono-FAME (40−45 wt%), and sat-FAME (50−55 wt%), which offered high oxidation stability and uncompromised cold-flow properties to lead to a new type of high-quality BDF suitable for use in high blends. coredata.dc:description: Facile synthesis of superficial Pd nanoparticles supported on carbonaceous SBA-15 (denoted as Pd/@SBA-15) as a new hydrotreating catalyst with enhanced activity and sulfur tolerance was accomplished for the production of partially hydrogenated fatty acid methyl esters (H-FAME), a high-quality biodiesel fuel enriched in monosaturated fatty acid methyl esters (mono-FAME) that can be used in high blends. Characterization, especially high-resolution electron microscopes and temperature-programmed techniques, indicated that the Pd nanoparticles (∼7 nm) formed spontaneously at the superficial area of carbonaceous SBA-15 with a hydrophobic surface and low acidity. In the synthesis of H-FAME using commercial palm oil-derived biodiesel fuel as a feedstock under mild conditions (<100 °C, 1 MPa), this new Pd/@SBA-15 catalyst offered high hydrotreating activity with excellent selectivity toward mono-FAME, especially the cis product, and high sulfur resistance, presumably due to fast diffusion and suitable interactions of the reactant and hydrogenated molecules through superficial Pd nanoparticles on the carbonaceous surfaces as the catalytically active sites. On the other hand, commercial Pd catalysts with Pd nanoparticles randomly impregnated inside the supporting materials showed lower activity in H-FAME synthesis and poorer selectivity toward saturated fatty acid methyl esters as undesirable products and lower sulfur tolerance level per Pd site, demonstrating the superiority of our system.
coredata.dc:title: Superficial Pd nanoparticles supported on carbonaceous SBA-15 as efficient hydrotreating catalyst for upgrading biodiesel fuel
